title: Android Location APIs are used in a wide variety of apps for different purposes such as finding user location, notifying when a user has left a general area (Geofencing), and help interpret user activity (walking, running, driving, etc).

inline_content.Text: Android Location APIs are used in a wide variety of apps for different purposes such as finding user location, notifying when a user has left a general area (Geofencing), and help interpret user activity (walking, running, driving, etc).

title: However, Android Location APIs are not the only means of acquiring user location. The following will give examples of how to use Android’s
LocationManager
c
and other common location libraries.

inline_content.Text: However, Android Location APIs are not the only means of acquiring user location. The following will give examples of how to use Android’s

title: For building Location aware apps in Android, there are two paths:

inline_content.Text: For building Location aware apps in Android, there are two paths:

title: Google’s
FusedLocationProviderApi
c
a
https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/location/FusedLocationProviderApi
, which is part of Google Play Services

inline_content.Text: , which is part of Google Play Services

title: Battery drain is an issue, if not managed properly

inline_content.Text: Battery drain is an issue, if not managed properly

title: Requires logic to switch location providers, if the device is unable to find a location (ex. poor GPS inside a building)

inline_content.Text: Requires logic to switch location providers, if the device is unable to find a location (ex. poor GPS inside a building)

title: Listen to provider status changes (ex. GPS is turned off by user)

inline_content.Text: Listen to provider status changes (ex. GPS is turned off by user)

title: List of providers to choose location source from

inline_content.Text: List of providers to choose location source from

title: Availability: Worldwide (with clear view of the sky)

inline_content.Text: Availability: Worldwide (with clear view of the sky)

title: Location updates typically come in once every second, but in situations where GPS has not been used for some time and
A-GPS
a
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assisted_GPS
is unavailable, it make take several minutes for a location to be received.

inline_content.Text: Location updates typically come in once every second, but in situations where GPS has not been used for some time and
is unavailable, it make take several minutes for a location to be received.

title: In cases where clear view of the sky is obstructed, GPS points will not cluster very well (location points “jump”) and accuracy may be misleading in certain areas due to the “
Urban Canyon
a
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Street_canyon
” effect.

inline_content.Text: In cases where clear view of the sky is obstructed, GPS points will not cluster very well (location points “jump”) and accuracy may be misleading in certain areas due to the “

title: Availability: Within range of cell tower or wifi signal

inline_content.Text: Availability: Within range of cell tower or wifi signal

title: Location updates occur less frequently than GPS

inline_content.Text: Location updates occur less frequently than GPS

title: Location updates typically do not cluster well (location points “jump”) and accuracy can range depending number of different factors (number of wifi signals, signal strength, type of cell tower, etc.)

inline_content.Text: Location updates typically do not cluster well (location points “jump”) and accuracy can range depending number of different factors (number of wifi signals, signal strength, type of cell tower, etc.)

title: Availability: Only when another app receives a location from either GPS or Network

inline_content.Text: Availability: Only when another app receives a location from either GPS or Network

title: Don’t rely on this to give you continuous updates. This listens passively to other apps that make location requests, and passes those locations back.

inline_content.Text: Don’t rely on this to give you continuous updates. This listens passively to other apps that make location requests, and passes those locations back.

title: Does not return FusedLocationProviderApi generated points, only the underlying location points used to generate them.

inline_content.Text: Does not return FusedLocationProviderApi generated points, only the underlying location points used to generate them.

title: Offers less battery drain “out of the box”

inline_content.Text: Offers less battery drain “out of the box”

title: May not be available on all devices or in certain countries

inline_content.Text: May not be available on all devices or in certain countries

title: Well managed use of location providers for optimal batter savings

inline_content.Text: Well managed use of location providers for optimal batter savings

title: Typically generates more accurate points then Network Location Provider

inline_content.Text: Typically generates more accurate points then Network Location Provider

title: More frequent updates of library, allowing for more improvement

inline_content.Text: More frequent updates of library, allowing for more improvement

title: No need to specify what type of provider to use

inline_content.Text: No need to specify what type of provider to use

title: Availability: Wherever Google Play Services is available.

inline_content.Text: Availability: Wherever Google Play Services is available.

title: If
ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION
c
a
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/Manifest.permission.html#ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION
is not used, this will not use GPS for generating location updates, but will still find a fairly accurate point in the right conditions.

inline_content.Text: is not used, this will not use GPS for generating location updates, but will still find a fairly accurate point in the right conditions.

title: If
ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION
c
a
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/Manifest.permission.html#ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION
is used, it may or may not use GPS to generate location points, depending on how accurate it can currently track the device given the environmental conditions.

inline_content.Text: is used, it may or may not use GPS to generate location points, depending on how accurate it can currently track the device given the environmental conditions.

title: Although this may report more accurate location updates than the other settings, it is still prone to the “
Urban Canyon

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Street_canyon
” effect.

title: Although it is unlikely, this setting may still use GPS to generate a location.

title: Since this seems to be a common issue with getting Android Locations, I’ll put down a quick checklist of common fixes:

inline_content.Text: Since this seems to be a common issue with getting Android Locations, I’ll put down a quick checklist of common fixes:

title: One of the most common issues is that the right permissions were never given. If you are using GPS (with or without Network), use
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION"/>
c
, else use
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION"/>
c
. Google’s FusedLocationApi requires
ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION
c

inline_content.Text: One of the most common issues is that the right permissions were never given. If you are using GPS (with or without Network), use

title: Check for and request permissions! If you are never given permissions, you’ll end up with crashes, or worse (if you are catching all exceptions), you’ll end up with no indication of anything! It doesn’t matter if the user grants you permission at the start of the app, always check to see if you have permissions for all calls. The user can easily go to their settings and revoke them.

inline_content.Text: Check for and request permissions! If you are never given permissions, you’ll end up with crashes, or worse (if you are catching all exceptions), you’ll end up with no indication of anything! It doesn’t matter if the user grants you permission at the start of the app, always check to see if you have permissions for all calls. The user can easily go to their settings and revoke them.

title: Are you sure you are passing in the right listener? Did you add that
BroadcastReceiver
c
or
IntentService
c
to your manifest? Are you using
PendingIntent.getService()
c
on a
BroadcastReceiver
c
class, or
getBroadcast()
c
on an
IntentService
c
class? Are you sure you are not unregistering your listener somewhere else in your code immediately after requesting?

inline_content.Text: Are you sure you are passing in the right listener? Did you add that
to your manifest? Are you using
class? Are you sure you are not unregistering your listener somewhere else in your code immediately after requesting?

title:
Obviously, make sure you have location services turned on.

[![enter image description here][8]][8]

If you are using Network services, did you turn on "Scanning Always Available"? Do you have your location mode set to "Best" ("High Accuracy") or "Battery Saving" ("Network Only")?

[![enter image description here][9]][9]

If you are using GPS, did you turn on "Best" ("High Accuracy") or "Device only" in location mode?

[![enter image description here][10]][10]

[![enter image description here][8]][8]

If you are using Network services, did you turn on "Scanning Always Available"? Do you have your location mode set to "Best" ("High Accuracy") or "Battery Saving" ("Network Only")?

[![enter image description here][9]][9]

If you are using GPS, did you turn on "Best" ("High Accuracy") or "Device only" in location mode?

[![enter image description here][10]][10]

LocationListener
c
instead of a
PendingIntent
c
, or vice-versa, to ensure you actually implemented
LocationManager
c
properly? Are you sure that the location request isn’t being removed in some part of the Activity or Service lifecycle that you didn’t expect to happen?

title: Are you testing GPS on the first floor of a building in the middle of San Francisco? Are you testing Network locations in the middle of nowhere? Do you work in a secret underground bunker void of all radio signals, wondering why your device isn’t getting location? Always double check your surroundings when trying to troubleshoot location problems!

inline_content.Text: Are you testing GPS on the first floor of a building in the middle of San Francisco? Are you testing Network locations in the middle of nowhere? Do you work in a secret underground bunker void of all radio signals, wondering why your device isn’t getting location? Always double check your surroundings when trying to troubleshoot location problems!

title: There could be many other less obvious reasons why location isn’t working, but before searching out those esoteric fixes, just run through this quick checklist.

inline_content.Text: There could be many other less obvious reasons why location isn’t working, but before searching out those esoteric fixes, just run through this quick checklist.
